title: How many seats will the United Russia party win in the 2021 Russian State Duma elections?
possible_answers: Russian State Duma elections will not be held before 20 September 2021
preds:
United Russia currently holds a super majority in parliament, winning 343 seats in 2016. However, election fraud has been a huge problem for Russian citizens. Leaders of the opposition party such as Alexey Navalny have been jailed or even exiled, and citizens who have supported opposition have been disenfranchised. Electronic voting and the severely limited ability to watch video streaming of polling stations by the CEC (Central Election Commission) have made it obvious that voting may be skewed. Most polls have reported United Russia to win around 300 seats, maintaining their majority. Despite this, the United Russia Party has seen its lowest popularity rating in 15 years - reported around and below 30% - suggesting the opposition will win seats in many of the single mandate districts where many United Russia candidates have done no campaigning at all. The amount of seats won by United Russia will likely depend on the severity of election fraud as well as voter turnout, which has also been low, reported at just around 31%. https://www.4freerussia.org/russian-state-duma-election-campaign-analysis-the-final-countdown/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=russian-state-duma-election-campaign-analysis-the-final-countdown&utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=russian-state-duma-election-campaign-analysis-the-final-countdown
https://www.orfonline.org/expert-speak/russia-votes-state-duma-elections-2021/
Just a technicality at this point... I have no clue.

There is a solid lesson here for flailing democracies everywhere - a bad lesson - These elections are not about winning or even about preventing United Russia from taking 226 seats. They are about forcing the Kremlin to de-legitimize itself to the point where the system breaks down and it is forced to make concessions. The problem with this strategy is the Kremlin’s other option is to increase repression and smother protest, which has already happened.
The United Russia Party currently has the majority of 340+ seats and has since the 2016 Russian elections.
The United Russian Party already holds the majority. There is no evidence to suggest for the elections being postponed.

The United Russian Party currently has over 300 seats. There does not seem like there is enough opposition for them to lose lose a substantial number of seats. There is no evidence to suggest that the elections will not be held.

I chose the probabilities above because the past year has shown a much higher probability of Russia getting 300+ seats so I put most of the percentage in that catagory and some in the between 226 and 299 seats.

Many opposition candidates have been advised or instructed to spend more time with their families.  If the results still don't look good enough, more will be disqualified or incarcerated during or directly after the vote counts but before this Q is resolved.  Another clutch of them will doubtless go missing after the new Duma is seated, but too late for this Q.   Several dozen will be left in office to show that Russia is a true democracy whose Beloved Leader values all viewpoints.  Not everyone will see it quite that way.

United Russia is polling well and they somehow always exceed their poll numbers. 
 Putin will not likely delay the election any further as not to appear Russia is doing worse with COVID than the rest of the world. 
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Russian_legislative_election

The Moscow Times is reporting little campaigning with Covid is having an effect and election debates appearing on tv’s graveyard slot with interest in politics at a 17-year low.
Expectations are that the United Russia party will retain its two-thirds majority.
The opposition is in disarray for a variety of issues. https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/09/03/russia-prepares-for-duma-vote-under-shadow-of-crackdown-on-dissent-a74964

2007 => 315
2011 => 238
2016 => 343
2021 => ?

Events like these is just a signal to me that they are after 2/3 majority
https://www.euronews.com/2021/05/18/russia-seeks-to-ban-navalny-supporters-from-running-in-elections also nice comment https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1328299 from @MCowley  and https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1329067 from @Greyowlsova

Critical development: in one of Moscow suburbs (Korolev, home of Roskosmos major plant) , somebody secretly made a recording of oral instructions for a group of election officials where ways of falsifying  of elections were discussed. Most probably, such discussions are being held all across Russia. The brazenness of instructions is shocking. The recording was given to Novaya Gazeta, one of the opposition newspapers, which forwarded the recording to the Central Election Committee.  The latter in turn asked law enforcement for a criminal investigation. https://www.rferl.org/a/united-russia-election-fraud/31442562.html So, what now? It is possible that because of this publicity, the powers-to-be can order scaling down the fraud and aim just for majority, not for 2/3 of the seats to have elections look legitimate after this scandal. It is also possible that to prevent the outcry, elections will be postponed. I think probabilities of those developments are close to zero. It is TOO important to get 2/3 of the vote as 2024 presidential elections will be within this Duma's term. For the ruling elite, the future of Russia is at stake. So they will scapegoat the instructor and continue with the election rigging. For me, the brazenness of this incident shows how in perfect control the elite is. Increasing the probability to 95%.

I'm finally shifting more heavily to >300. Duma is 450 seats with 225 assigned to FPtP constituencies and 225 assign to proportional representation, the only change to the 2016 election has been the INCREASE in additional parties (1). Latest polling has RU at ~30%, 15 points clear of their nearest rival. which should deliver a similar number to 2016 for the FPtP constituencies - call it 200 (2). While 30% of 225 is only 68, there is a 5% minimum threshold to win a seat from the Proportional Representation pool. Which means, based on current polling, RU's 30% is actually closer to 50% of the PR pool, as the combined percentage points of parties over the 5% threshold is 62% , meaning over 110 seats for RU. Turns out Putin didn't need to reform the system to maintain RU's hold over parliament, he just had to give the Russian people more choice. 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Russian_legislative_election
2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Russian_legislative_election

I have reversed my position given the hurdles that the opposition face.
‘The elections will be held over three days from September 17-19, rather than just one, making it harder for poll monitors to compare the number of total voters to the votes claimed by United Russia’. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/aug/29/ruling-united-russia-party-offers-payouts-to-ensure-poll-victory
I don't have a good sense of this question at all, but the cards seem to be gradually stacked in favour of Putin, so shifting my probabilities again.

Putin and United Russia have promised to pay $ 140 to all pensioners and military, about $ 7 billion from the state budget will be spent on this after the Duma elections.
https://iz.ru/1211281/2021-08-23/vyplaty-voennym-i-pensioneram-obespechat-za-schet-dopdokhodov-biudzheta

Expect the election fraud that took place in 2016 to take place once again.  Putin's approval rating is high, though Medvedev's wasn't (former PM).  Supermajority of around 300 seats allows for changing Constitution.  Seems like Putin would want to keep that option open for now. Elections in Belarus were rigged due to Russian influence in 2019. Seat history is 343 (2016), 238 (2011), 315 (2007), 223 (2003)

The 2021 Elections are considered important as a precursor to the 2024 Presidential elections to secure a constitutional majority in the Duma to allow the ruling party to continue control of law-making process and symbolically to maintain an image of stability and invincibility. The Russian state controls political parties where those who do not comply are constrained in their activities.
Putin is considered by the majority as ‘a unifying national symbol and the guarantor of stability.’
‘The lack of change and the management of any opposition can result in voter compliance where there is paternal sentiment, in regard to the State especially where the State is the only provider of employment and/or support.’
Current ratings suggest that the United Russia Party will win a simple majority of 226 and/or  will they win a constitutional majority that is 300+ seats (two-thirds) to allow them to amend the constitution unilaterally.
There are new rules that will allow parts of Eastern Ukraine to vote in the election which should add to the United Russia party’s count.
The Russian economy rebounded by an increase of the GDP by 10.3% in the third quarter, experiencing only one Covid inspired lockdown and an increase in the crude oil price. This may convert into an inflationary spike prior to the election.
I will suggest that Russians being more used to dramatic societal changes than most, will vote for stability and the status quo, but perhaps limited by the declining popularity votes. https://carnegie.ru/commentary/84722  https://theconversation.com/vladimir-putin-plans-to-win-russias-parliamentary-election-no-matter-how-unpopular-his-party-is-160078  https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/08/13/russian-economy-rebounds-in-second-quarter-a74786
https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/08/13/rosneft-profit-up-on-higher-oil-prices-a74781  https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/08/12/can-team-putin-rebrand-save-united-russia-a74765

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Russian_legislative_election#2021
Seat projections have UR winning 51pc of the projected seats, which would give them 230 seats in total.  Which is pretty low compared to the past. Although that assessment has to be carefully considered as the seats projected might not have the same probability as the unprojected seats. Opinion polls look to be maintaining about the 30pc vote mark, but I’m guessing that as a poll this might not be that reliable Votes from the Donbass region of the Ukraine could be interesting, I wonder whose seat that would contribute to? https://tass.com/politics/1317093 Impact of first time votes might also be interesting https://www.chathamhouse.org/publications/the-world-today/2021-08/putins-problem-children https://www.memri.org/reports/russias-upcoming-elections  Interesting article arguing now change on this election, but the next will be a big change because of the age of all the well known leaders. The most interesting comment is that a lot of previous UR officials are standing as independents because of the reduced popularity of UR.  That will not change the true profile of the Duma, but it could have a big impact on this question because those independents will not count for UR on this question.  As they are known people and UR may have a competing candidate, they could win a number of seats.  Can’t work out how this might play into the game.

Russia excludes senior Communist candidate from parliamentary vote - Reuters
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-excludes-senior-communist-candidate-parliamentary-vote-2021-07-24/
Sat, 24 Jul 2021 13:21:00 GMT > Pavel Grudinin, who won 12% of votes when he challenged Vladimir Putin in a 2018 presidential election, was excluded from a candidate list because the Prosecutor's Office had found he held shares in a foreign company, news agencies reported. (!) Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny's website blocked by regulator before election - Reuters
https://www.reuters.com/world/kremlin-critic-navalnys-website-blocked-by-russian-regulator-2021-07-26/
Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:27:00 GMT Communist Party plans pickets across Russia after election officials reject Pavel Grudinin’s State Duma candidacy - Meduza
https://meduza.io/en/news/2021/07/27/communist-party-plans-pickets-across-russia-after-election-officials-reject-pavel-grudinin-s-state-duma-candidacy
Tue, 27 Jul 2021 18:00:00 GMT On Russia's Upcoming Elections - Middle East Media Research Institute
https://www.memri.org/reports/russias-upcoming-elections
Wed, 28 Jul 2021 14:43:50 GMT > This scenario is set to be repeated another time – the only difference is that many members of the United Russia Party now prefer to run as independents as overall party approval figures decline.[6] Since the party's insignia features a bear, these people are commonly referred to with a pun that combines the Russian words for "self-nominated candidates" and "bear," implying that these so-called independents are in fact put forward by the "bear," i.e., the United Russia Party. > I should say that since 1993, all federal election campaigns in Russia have been organized according to different rules from those that applied to elections before that point. This time there are two novelties in place: First, it will be the first parliamentary election with internet voting (permitted in Moscow and Sevastopol [both have "federal entity" status], as well as in Nizhny Novgorod, Yaroslavl, Kursk, Murmansk, and Rostov region);[7] second, the votes will be cast for three consecutive days, from September 17-19. This makes fraud easier, but, of course, it is explained by the coronavirus pandemic that, since early June, is once again plaguing Russia.[8] > The ruling party's opponents have all become "niche" parties that are simply doing nothing to broaden their electorate. The Communists still rely on the older generation, capitalizing on post-Soviet nostalgia (there have been several rare cases in which they proposed more modern and open-minded candidates, like Vitaly Petrov, an ex­perienced former Ministry of the Economic Development employee and who now runs in a single constituency in Moscow, who produced huge unrest in the party).[9] The Liberal Democrats support Russian nationalism inside the country, proposing more solid leadership from the center and less autonomy for the nati­onal republics. The Just Russia party, which previously had been a kind of Social-Democratic party, is now headed by a trio of leaders, one of whom is Zakhar Prilepin,[10] a talented writer who openly dismisses the sovereignty of now independent post-Soviet states[11] and has spent time in Donbass fighting the Ukrainian army on the side of local separatists.[12]

Rumours of delay due to pandemic
https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-duma-vote-postponement/31352116.html Another step down in the polls for united russia from 30pc to 28pc.  Yes to see if maintained, but something has happened
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_next_Russian_legislative_election Still think the manipulation will get them over the line, but delay seems possible and maybe desirable for Putin if there is any doubt, and the pandemic gives a convenient excuse.

Assuming, or rather hoping, that a new wave of covid would not prevent elections from being held at the scheduled date. I do not think that United Russia would fall below the majority number of seats, the President has been busy consolidating his power and, should there be a need, a bit of good'ol fraud can always come in handy.
That’s right ho’s. Duma ain’t for Russia.

https://meduza.io/en/news/2021/05/26/russian-lawmakers-adopt-legislation-banning-people-linked-to-extremist-organizations-from-running-in-elections @yagudin, any thoughts?
Putin seems to be changing things in his favour

Party of power is united, projects (paradoxically) both change (by admitting new and younger candidates through primaries) and continuity (with the same known people at the helm). They have many tools to keep the "constitutional" majority. Most probably, they get it with "one-mandate" seats. Whatever you hear, the wider society is not in the mood for protests unless something drastic comes up. And probability of that is gradually diminishing.

1) Establishing base rate/trend: looking at all results since 2001, URP has gained over half of total seats each time, with an increasing trend (lots of variation and n=5) in the amount of seats in that the URP gets.
2) There is the question of whether the result is free or controlled. Freedom House speaks of 'controlled elections' but no full-blown dictatorship results (e.g. North Korea). Combined with 1), this means low chances of a result below 226. 
3) In 2020 the results of the constitutional election showed significantly more support for the constitution than ex ante independent polling. This might be a sign that the polls underpredict results for the ruling party. 
4) in a controlled setting, the risks of cancelling an election are low. The optics of cancelling elections are poor (costs are high) whereas you are not concerned about the result anyway (returns are low). 
5) at the same time, polling shows Putin's popularity at an all-time low. All in all: chance of cancellation and fewer than 226 seats seem improbable because of the controlled nature of the elections. Looking at past elections, the result can go over 300 or under. Putin's popularity drop gives some indication that it might be under, but the effect of such matters on elections in Russia are to be debated. As a result under 300 would mean a significant drop off from its current level of 336, chances seem lower that that result will be allowed. It's a close call, but balancing everything I would say it is just a little likelier that they'll remain over 300.

The fpp system gets them most of the seats where an opposition is fragmented.   Then supplemented by the proportional allocation gets UR easily over 300.  It is unlikely a fragmented and squabbling opposition can unite for strategic voting.

Many opposition politicians and their supporters will be spending more time with their families in the near future.  Probably in the scenic locales of Hа Kладбище and B Tюрьме.  The true patriots of United Russia will emerge victorious, or at least alive and at large.

The Kremlin is doing a lot of work to crush any potential rivals, which means that if there is no high profile challenge in the months up to the election people will believe sticking with UR is the right thing to do However the polls remain at 30pc and a quiet background discussion on tactical voting may have been instigated.  If the tactical voting of “anyone bar UR” theory works, alternative candidates are not needed.  Even if these alternatives are in the pocket of the Kremlin it would be a way for voters so send a message without risking their own safety. However it’s not clear how established these ideas are and whether the people who would promote them are actually able to, as they are the ones being targeted by the new laws. I have to be realistic and say it’s most likely UR will get over 300 seats, but there is still a likelihood it could be less.  Changing forecast to reflect this. https://www.reuters.com/world/defiant-cornered-jailed-kremlin-critic-navalnys-movement-is-ropes-2021-05-06/
A carefully calculated final outcome of 340 to 360 will represent a confident majority in a democracy as against 400 seats and allegations of ballot fraud. some opposition will be retained.

This is a federal election.
About 80 percent voted to approve 2020 amendments making Putin President or Tsar for life. Putin will be out before 2030 but not now.
While opposition parties have won Provincial governor mayor and council elections in Far East.
Now with Navalny in jail and Vladivostok provincial governor of far right in jail,
Why would he not ensure United Russia wins a 2/3
Majority necessary for constitutional changes?
 the crowd seems to assume for a 53 to 47 split on. I forecast 70 percent of Sums seats go to United Russia. There seems to be assumption there will be free and fair Duma elections and polls do show declining popularity of United Russia Count on no free and fair Duma elections .
There are a variety of constitutional amendments that Putin might need to make....further dilution of governor power and further integration of Belarus.No free and fair elections with OSCE monitors. I am not sure there is even 10 likelihood
Putin will grab less than 300 what ever vote

Looks like United Russia are polling at 30pc, way down from 50pc at last election.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_next_Russian_legislative_election (although these polls are not for all seats it seems according to the Wikipedia page). They lost 2 seats at last elections in sept https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-54135141 But united Russia is so dominant and the situation tense I guess there will manoeuvring to ensure that people from other parties can’t even get on the lists for election.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Russian_legislative_election If there was 50pc support at last election and they got 340 seats out of 450 then with 30pc it feels like the number would be somewhere between 200 and 300 seats. 28/03/21 adding some more links.
New legislation banning people from running for 5 years for low level felonies combined with tactics of arresting large groups of elected officials is a clever tactic, that will manipulate who can stand and help United Russia will.  Tipping slightly more to 300 seats.
https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/ukrainealert/putin-turns-up-pressure-on-russian-opposition-ahead-of-september-duma-elections/
https://tass.com/politics/1269733
They will lose some seats because they are less popular. But I see no reason to expect a major loss, although there is a small possibility of that too.
Basing on current polls as of 14 March and thanks to the insights from @Eolienne.
Time to lower my extreme projection. Recent developments beat expectations (vote for constitutional changes come to mind). So my forecast is still biased toward United Russia. May change later
Upgrading 226-299 based on latest polls - thanks @Eolienne

Adjusting slightly as previous forecast didn't take into account that half the seats are first past the post and UR seems have fairly consistent lead in different areas despite around a 40% drop in polling since the last election.  Last time around (2016) UR won 140 of party list seats and 203 of fptp seats.  However even if you assumed all 203 fptp seats are kept and the party list seats dropped by 40% you would still be well below 300 seats, you'd need only a 32% drop in party list seats only to get below 300.  Therefore I am still rating 226-299 as slightly more likely.

Looks like United Russia are polling at 30pc, way down from 50pc at last election.

They lost 2 seat at last elections in sept https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-54135141 But united Russia is so dominant and the situation tense I guess there will manoeuvring to ensure that people from other parties can’t even get on the lists for election.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Russian_legislative_election If there was 50pc support at last election and they got 340 seats out of 450 then with 30pc it feels like the number would be somewhere between 200 and 300 seats.

United Russia's polling isn't great, and the opposition seems more organised this time around tactical voting, so it should be a tougher election. The party itself seems to be expecting around 300 seats (https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/01/05/russia-in-2021-looming-elections-dominate-the-domestic-scene-a72391), so I will show an equal probability between below and above 300.  The chances of them losing/expecting to lose their majority should be slim (5%), with any chance of them losing power surely resulting in a postponement (5% covid + 4% expected loss of majority).
A bit more complicated here. Finlandization in reverse.  Russia will probably not allow elections. Too much interference. How many members of the United Russia Party have visited Finland?

can I make a punn here, if Putin feels threatened...
Look for nearve gas.

Navalny's been sentenced early enough and to a term long enough to bury him (hopefully not literally) for the duration necessary to pull off the election off without substantial interference from the opposition (though admittedly, the protests in support of Navalny are pretty widespread).  These questions are very tough to forecast because, well, in addition to the challenge of forecasting election outcomes, we have to tip our hat to the ability of the government to "adjust" outcomes themselves. So then we need to think about the strategy that might be in play for the government itself. It used to be, we could simply comfortably predict near 100%! Hooray! Now, we need to think about a more nuanced approach to strong-armed interference in elections.
"I think that United Russia has all chances of getting the majority, [but] hard work is needed for that," Dmitry Medvedev said.

I am late with my forecast. I can write a LONG description about 2 different ways how delegates are elected and how this system is skewed toward the ruling party. How the latter uses "administrative resources" or rather abuses its powers and access to media, money, government structures... How real politics is done in Russia - with parties negotiate BEFOREHAND who is going to be allowed to win election in a certain district - like power sharing agreement with "formal opposition". Of course, there is "non-formal opposition" - Navalny and alike - but they are divided, not that numerous and in the eyes of a significant portion of the populace are considered "foreign agents". It can be a long boring analysis that neither you, nor I are interested in writing/reading. Yes, the polls indicate quite a drop in approval of United Russia compared to 2016 now. Well, the state is prepared to dole out money for the doubtful, to stimulate whatever they want to stimulate in order to get "qualified majority" of 301 delegates. The vaccine rollout also helps - shows how great Russia is. And, in the eyes of significant portion of the populace, in other countries a lot of people want Putin to be THEIR president as well. Or so Russian TV says...
No, i do not think it is 100%. But I need to compensate for being late. My personal views - and I sincerely admit that I do not have a crystal ball

The economy is not good (which is normal), but the citizens are hardier than the western electorate, given the experience over the last few years.
Navalny may be a high profile with younger activists but is not particularly popular elsewhere.

Long way to go and over 300 still feels most likely but he's clearly hit a nerve with his 'palace' video https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-55732296. He's a canny campaigner. To only election they have slipped below 226 was their first in 2003, since then their results have been; 315 in 2007 under Boris Gryzlov
238 in 2011 under Vladimir Putin
343 in 2016 under Dmitry Medvedev It's worth noting that the Duma is elected by "half of the seats (225) are elected by party-list proportional representation with a 5% electoral threshold, with the other half elected in 225 single-member constituencies by first-past-the-post voting." (1) Assuming this is still the case come election day, and we scale the preference for UR proportionally to sit at about 42% (normalised to remove undecided and absentia counts in the polls), and their next highest party at 17.5%. We lock a base line of  ~95 seats to UR.  Now of the remaining seats, this doesn't break down along % lines, with so many parties running FPtP system HUGELY favours a party that has such a wide lead in a multi horse race. In 2016 UR won 203/225 seats with 50.1% of the vote (2).  Even with their dip in polling, I'm thinking they will lose some seats in this upcoming election, but the question will be how many, and what number Putin would like to pick as his margin of victory for this election, and more importantly will he want to make a point about his control, Russian unity and solidarity, in the wake of Covid and international pressures in various areas.  1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Russian_legislative_election#Electoral_system
2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Russian_legislative_election#Results

Based on historic trends alone, there's around 50% probability of more than 300 seats, but recent trends would suggest otherwise with support for United Russia significantly down since last election, when they won 339 seats. While the Kremlin did have good local elections in autumn, probably through heavy manipulation, given scale of social unrest in recent years, it might be too big a risk to rig the Duma elections too much this year, and so a simple majority in the 226-299 range is probably the most likely. That said, the creation of new systemic opposition parties enables United Russia party protect a large majority in the Duma without increasing its vote share, by splitting the opposition vote. This tactic could however be countered by the real opposition if they can promote 'smart voting' strategies to gather the opposition vote. Altogether, lean towards the simple majority option, therefore.

I haven't dived too deeply into this, but it looks like the 225 seats (if the election were held today, assuming polls are correct) that are proportional representation would have maybe 80 go to United Russia? With such a divided opposition they'll get most of the 225 winner-take-all seats, but they'll have to really run the table on those.  I hate to be too far off from the crowd though, so setting this at 85% for now.
